Award.AwardTitle: SPRF-IBSS: Applying structural equation modeling to populations undergoing economic transition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Economic transition is occurring rapidly in developing countries and resulting in a myriad of social, behavioral and biologic changes. This research focuses on immune function's relationship to behavioral, psychosocial and community factors.

The first research question focuses on whether physical activity/sedentary behavior is a mediating influence on the relationship between lifestyle incongruity (an indicator of psychosocial stress) and immune function in indigenous Siberian adults. The second research question is whether community level market integration in indigenous Amazonian children and adults predictive of biological outcomes. The third research question is whether in community level market integration over a five year period predictive of biological outcomes in indigenous Amazonian children and adults.

Intellectual Merit:

These complex relationships require advanced bio-statistical techniques to properly analyze. This project focuses on learning structural equation modeling (SEM) and applying the versatile statistical method to questions regarding the biological outcomes of transition in indigenous populations.

The research questions are assessed using data from a sample of Sakha (Yakut) adults of Siberia in 2009 and the Tsimane Annual Panel Survey in Bolivia in 2002-2009. The mediating effect of physical activity and sedentary behavior on the relationship between lifestyle incongruity and biological outcomes in Yakut adults will be assessed using SEM path analysis. The influence of community market integration and five year change in community market integration on biological outcomes in Tsimane? adults and children will be assessed using multi-level SEM.

This research utilizes multi-disciplinary techniques to: 1) provide insight into the pathways through which psychosocial stress influences immune function; 2) advance understanding of the community influence on biology. The research team succesfully exploits the pairing of advanced statistical training and biology to advocate for quantitative approaches to measuring the effects of economic transition on physical health. Additionally, the proposed activities are interdisciplinary to the extent that the research draws from and speaks to issues that are pertinent within several fields including human biology, anthropology, sociology, health economics, physiology, demography, and behavioral ecology.


Broader Impacts:

Achieving the research goals and disseminating the findings to researchers and local populations increases understanding of the impacts of economic and social transition on biological outcomes in the developing world. It also increases awareness of the usefulness of advanced biostatistical techniques within human biology and bioanthropology research. In addition, this Fellowship project integrates research and education at many different levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided two years of postdoctoral funding for Dr. Hannah Wilson, working in collaboration with Dr. William Leonard at Northwestern University. The goal of this project was to evaluate the health effects of lifestyle transition in two different indigenous populations – the Yakut of northeastern Siberia (Russia) and the Tsimane’ of lowland Bolivia. Dr. Wilson participated in field research in both of the study areas, working among the Yakut of in the summer/fall of 2013, and among the Tsimane' in the summer of 2015. With the Yakut research, Wilson examined the influence of lifestyle change on a variety of biological/health parametesr, including: a) activity patterns, b) sleep patterns, and c) patterns of childhood growth and nutritional status. With the Tsimane’ study, Wilson oversaw the implementation of data collection on physical activity among Tsimane’ children and adults. 

Among the Yakut, Wilson’s research demonstrated strong gender differences in physical activity levels and cardiovascular diseases risks. Yakut men spent significantly more time in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) that Yakut women.  Greater levels of MVPA were related to lower risk of cardio-metabolic risk factor clustering within this sample of Yakut men, but not women. Thus, the maintenance of high physical activity levels appears to contribute to a reduction in clustering of metabolic risk factors within indigenous arctic populations.

Additionally, Wilson’s work documented surprisingly high rates of disturbed sleep patterns among Yakut adults.  Trouble sleeping was reported by 18.5% of the participants and excessive daytime sleepiness was reported by 17.3%. Sleeping difficulties were more common among women and older adults, and were also observed more commonly in households with greater articulation to the market economy.  Ongoing work is exploring the potential impact of sleep problems on cardiovascular health.

 Wilson’s work clearly demonstrated that Yakut children have better/healthier growth profiles than those of other Siberian groups, such as the Evenki, Ket and Nganasan.  Rates of growth stunting (low height-for-age) are significantly lower in the Yakut relative to the Evenki and Ket.  Additionally, weight-for-height measures show very low levels of acute nutritional stress.

Work among the Tsimane’ documented marked declines in physical activity levels with acculturation, contributing to higher rates of overweight and increased risks of cardiovascular disease. 

Overall, Wilson’s research greatly expanded our understanding of the multiple pathways through which lifestyle change affects chronic health outcomes in acculturating populations around the world.

 

This grant provided two years of postdoctoral funding for Dr. Hannah Wilson, working in collaboration with Dr. William Leonard at Northwestern University. The goal of this project was to evaluate the health effects of lifestyle transition in two different indigenous populations – the Yakut of northeastern Siberia (Russia) and the Tsimane’ of lowland Bolivia. Dr. Wilson participated in field research in both of the study areas, working among the Yakut of in the summer/fall of 2013, and among the Tsimane' of Bolivia in the summer of 2015. With the Yakut research, Wilson examined the influence of lifestyle change on a variety of biological/health parameter, including: a) activity patterns, b) sleep patterns, and c) patterns of childhood growth and nutritional status. With the Tsimane’ study, Wilson oversaw the implementation of data collection on physical activity among Tsimane’ children and adults. 

Among the Yakut, Wilson’s research demonstrated strong gender differences in physical activity levels and cardiovascular diseases risks. Yakut men spent significantly more time in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) that Yakut women.  Greater levels of MVPA were related to lower risk of cardio-metabolic risk factor clustering within this sample of Yakut men, but not women. Thus, the maintenance of high physical activity levels appears to contribute to a reduction in clustering of metabolic risk factors within indigenous arctic populations.

Additionally, Wilson’s work documented surprisingly high rates of disturbed sleep patterns among Yakut men and women.  Trouble sleeping was reported by 18.5% of the participants and excessive daytime sleepiness was reported by 17.3%. Sleeping difficulties were more common among women and older adults, and were also observed more commonly in households with greater articulation to the market economy.  Ongoing work is exploring the potential impact of sleep problems on cardiovascular health.

Wilson’s work clearly demonstrated that Yakut children have better/healthier growth profiles than those of other Siberian groups, such as the Evenki, Ket and Nganasan.  Rates of growth stunting (low height-for-age) are significantly lower in the Yakut relative to the Evenki and Ket.  Additionally, weight-for-height measures show very low levels of acute nutritional stress.

Work among the Tsimane’ documented marked declines in physical activity levels with acculturation, contributing to higher rates of overweight and obesity, and increased risks of cardiovascular disease. 

Overall, Wilson’s research greatly expanded our understanding of the multiple pathways through which lifestyle change affects chronic health outcomes in acculturating populations around the world.  This work has resulted in three refereed publications, six poster or paper presentations, with two other manuscripts currently in preparation.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This grant provided two years of postdoctoral funding for Dr. Hannah Wilson, working in collaboration with Dr. William Leonard at Northwestern University. The goal of this project was to evaluate the health effects of lifestyle transition in two different indigenous populations – the Yakut of northeastern Siberia (Russia) and the Tsimane? of lowland Bolivia. Dr. Wilson participated in field research in both of the study areas, working among the Yakut of in the summer/fall of 2013, and among the Tsimane' in the summer of 2015. With the Yakut research, Wilson examined the influence of lifestyle change on a variety of biological/health parametesr, including: a) activity patterns, b) sleep patterns, and c) patterns of childhood growth and nutritional status. With the Tsimane? study, Wilson oversaw the implementation of data collection on physical activity among Tsimane? children and adults. Among the Yakut, Wilson?s research demonstrated strong gender differences in physical activity levels and cardiovascular diseases risks. Yakut men spent significantly more time in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) that Yakut women. Greater levels of MVPA were related to lower risk of cardio-metabolic risk factor clustering within this sample of Yakut men, but not women. Thus, the maintenance of high physical activity levels appears to contribute to a reduction in clustering of metabolic risk factors within indigenous arctic populations. Additionally, Wilson?s work documented surprisingly high rates of disturbed sleep patterns among Yakut adults. Trouble sleeping was reported by 18.5% of the participants and excessive daytime sleepiness was reported by 17.3%. Sleeping difficulties were more common among women and older adults, and were also observed more commonly in households with greater articulation to the market economy. Ongoing work is exploring the potential impact of sleep problems on cardiovascular health. Wilson?s work clearly demonstrated that Yakut children have better/healthier growth profiles than those of other Siberian groups, such as the Evenki, Ket and Nganasan. Rates of growth stunting (low height-for-age) are significantly lower in the Yakut relative to the Evenki and Ket. Additionally, weight-for-height measures show very low levels of acute nutritional stress. Work among the Tsimane? documented marked declines in physical activity levels with acculturation, contributing to higher rates of overweight and increased risks of cardiovascular disease. Overall, Wilson?s research greatly expanded our understanding of the multiple pathways through which lifestyle change affects chronic health outcomes in acculturating populations around the world.
